titre_video: Wildlife Backyard Habitat (Ultimate Yard for Animal and Nature Lovers)
description:
Nice work Team Marketing! You are amazing!

Wildlife Backyard Habitat (Ultimate Yard for Animal and Nature Lovers)  

Today‚Äôs video is about how you can be attracted to your outdoor space - in this video we're going to talk to you about how we can attract wildlife into your outdoor space. About what that wildlife will do for you but also, what it will do for the ecosystem of your backyard space. It‚Äôs important for your kids to see how creating this backyard ecosystem will really benefit your family and also benefit the in your neighborhood.

 Ways to attract wildlife to your backyard is of course ‚Äì water. All animals need fresh water and there are many ways to bring water to backyards. Beautiful cascading water features, meandering brooks, even too small ponds will be magnets. Water also does a great job for attracting birds to a birdbath they created from your water feature. See how they are attracted to this water feature? It's amazing. Notice the birds are a bit apprehensive about coming close 'cause of us filming - but look at what adding a water feature to a landscape does.  It attracts so many birds and so much wildlife.

Adding a backyard birdhouse is an amazing way to attract wildlife to your backyard. I would even say add two and three. Create a safe and cozy space for your birds and have a rewarding adventure. Have fun watching this inspiring life cycle of birds. When a bird nests on your property - they're gonna raise their young - it's fun to know you are responsible for a little bird family in your backyard. It is also nice to teach our kids from this. If you think about adding birdhouses - research this and see what types of birdhouses will attract the birds that you would like to attract.

One of the main benefits of creating and attracting wildlife to your backyard is teaching your kids that man & wildlife all live together and benefit one another. Backyard habitats support and encourage growth in a variety of species. If you‚Äôve had a pond in your backyard - you realize how much wildlife it attracts. Remember spring days when frogs start to populate & then a symphony begins in our backyard every night?  A pond attracts frogs - you will either love it or go crazy because of how many frogs now live in your backyard!

An instant way to bring wildlife into your backyard space is by adding a backyard koi pond or goldfish pond. This will instantly bring wildlife to your exterior space. Once put koi or goldfish in the space it‚Äôs starts of the benefits. Koi or goldfish have been known to relax the homeowner - stress relief at the end of the day as you head outside to relax and feed them - relaxing with nature - being at one with the outside, with wildlife. As you contemplate what to do for your backyard space, think Koi pond as it can bring nature to your backdoor and attract other wildlife.

Squeamish earthworms? The benefit of earthworms in your soil will help keep everything organic while adding nutrients. Having a healthy amount of worms in your backyard also fertilizes the soil.

A new popular feature in backyards are beehives. Bring the bumblebees into your backyard with plantings for attracting them as well as butterflies - you will love being in your backyard - enjoying the wildlife - enjoying the beautiful butterflies & the bees.

My favorite is Hummingbirds. They can be attracted by a hummingbird feeder (sugar water) throughout all seasons including winter. They love native flowers too. You are able to enjoy and hang out in your beautiful garden space with them.

Uh oh, let‚Äôs not forget one of the most entertaining of wildlife critters to invite into your backyard space - the beloved squirrel and you can love 'em or they can drive you crazy depending on what your backyard environment is most set for.  A typical bird feeder might be very hard if not impossible to keep the squirrels away from. In the Forest property, the homeowner set up two squirrel feeders. It‚Äô fun to be able to watch from the window as they are incredibly agile and able to find ways to get through even difficult obstacle courses. T

Another popular way to attract wildlife to your backyard (a little bit controversial) is building a bat house. Why would you ever want to build a bat house in your backyard? There are many benefits to bringing a few bats to your backyard. First - bats love to eat mosquitoes. Mosquitoes love to eat humans. Even one little Brown bat can eat over 1000 mosquitoes in one night! They are also fascinating to watch as the sun begins to go down. You begin seeing flashes of shadows in the evenings.

So wasn't it fun to talk about all the different ways we can attract wildlife to our backyard space? Thanks for joining us.

titre_video: Chopping Wood in the Countryside: Girl's Daily Labor
description:
What's happening**: The video shows a girl chopping wood with an axe beside a countryside forest. She stands next to a pile of logs, skillfully lifting the axe and accurately splitting the wood, showcasing a common labor scene in rural life.

What it is**: This is a common labor scene in rural life, showing the girl's physical exercise and skill development through wood - chopping, reflecting the self - sufficiency and close connection with nature in rural living.

Fun fact**: In rural areas, wood - chopping is a common labor activity. Choosing the right wood and tools is crucial. When chopping wood, select dry wood of appropriate hardness to ensure efficiency and safety. Proper axe - holding posture and chopping angle improve efficiency and reduce physical exertion.

titre_video: Planting the Native Australian Food Forest on our homestead
description:
Make sure to SUBSCRIBE so you don't miss any parts of this journey.
http://www.youtube.com/c/DianeandSamson?sub_confirmation=1
New videos twice a week!

And so it begins! The Australian Native food forest is about to be planted. I want to celebrate and showcase the Australian bush foods that grow native around parts of NSW and some from other parts of Australia. It doesn't look like much yet, but over the next few weeks see how the forest will change from native forest trees to incredible edible varieties. Bush foods are the ultimate super food so lets learn about them together. Today I am preparing the food forest and mapping it out. I hope this next series serves as a Guide for anyone thinking of growing native Australian edible plants in a food forest or in their garden. Think of it as a  temperate food forests for beginners. A helpful cheat sheet for starting a permaculture food forest with Australian natives. 

For those that are new we're homesteading in Australia and have been homesteading here for a year. This is only our temporary homestead, so we hope to take you along on our journey of learning trialing and growing a homestead. This native Australian food forest is our next project to celebrate reaching our 500 subscriber goal. We want to create a food forest with Australian native edibles as living in Australia we have a lot of harsh weather, droughts, and sometimes fires. Planting native edible plants makes sense as they will grow well, are well adapted and are high in nutrients, minerals and packed with flavour like you have never had before.We are starting a food forest Australia because there is not enough information out there to make us feel comfortable having a go at using all these incredible ingredients in our own backyards. Australian bush tucker is the way forward here in our temperate, but erratic Australian climate. It is my hope that you will experiment with some Australian native edibles in your garden or even just trial using some new ingredients in your cooking derived from Australian native edible plants. 

#australiannativefoodforest #bushtucker #foodforestaustralia

titre_video: ECOKRAFT - Fermentation residues & cocoa shells to energy pellets
description:
Fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be converted into energy pellets, which are a more convenient and versatile form of fuel than loose materials. Energy pellets are typically made by compressing the materials into small, dense pellets using a pellet mill. The pellets can then be used for a variety of applications, such as heating buildings or generating electricity.

There are several advantages to converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets:

1. Efficient use of waste materials: By converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets, waste materials can be put to productive use instead of being discarded or causing environmental problems.

2. Renewable energy source: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells are a renewable energy source that can be produced on an ongoing basis. This reduces the reliance on non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels.

3. Lower greenhouse gas emissions: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells have lower greenhouse gas emissions than traditional fossil fuels. This can help to reduce the overall carbon footprint of energy production.

4. Cost-effective: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be a cost-effective fuel source, particularly if the materials are readily available and inexpensive.

5. Versatile: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be used in a variety of applications, such as heating buildings, generating electricity, and fueling industrial processes.

Overall, converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets can be an environmentally friendly and cost-effective way to produce renewable energy. It can also help to 
reduce waste and greenhouse gas emissions.

titre_video: Laurent producteur de pois chiches nous pr√©sente sa vision de l'agriculture. #16
description:
Dans cet √©pisode Laurent, producteur de pois chiches r√©pond aux questions suivantes, choisissez votre passage :
00:30 Est-ce que tu peux te pr√©senter et nous dire ce que tu fais ? 
01:00 Qu‚Äôest-ce qui t‚Äôa fait te convertir au bio ?
02:00 Est-ce que ce c√¥t√© local et terroir, √ßa a du sens ?
02:35 Est-ce que tu n‚Äôas pas √©t√© un peu pr√©curseur ? 
03:25 Dans 10 ans o√π en serons-nous c√¥t√© agricole ?
04:09 Laurent, as-tu un dernier message pour changer le monde ?

Salut c‚Äôest Agathe. Bienvenue dans Paroles de Terres ! Je suis toujours dans ma saga Pois chiches. Mais aujourd‚Äôhui je le range dans ma poche car vous vous souvenez de Laurent : il nous a fait d√©couvrir le pois chiche d‚ÄôOccitanie, et bien aujourd‚Äôhui j‚Äôai envie d‚Äôen savoir un petit peu plus sur lui, qui il est, son parcours. Allez, c‚Äôest parti !

- Bonjour Laurent. 
- Bonjour Agathe.
- Merci de nous avoir parl√© de ton exploitation, de tes pois chiches, de ta farine de pois chiches. Aujourd‚Äôhui j‚Äôaimerais qu‚Äôon parle un petit peu plus de toi, est-ce que tu peux te pr√©senter et nous dire ce que tu fais ? 
- Je vis en Occitanie, je suis mari√©, j‚Äôai deux enfants, une fille de 20 ans et un gar√ßon de 17 ans, et je suis agriculteur en bio.
- Tu t‚Äôes install√© sur ton exploitation √† la suite de tes parents ? 
- En 1997 j‚Äôai repris l‚Äôexploitation familiale. J‚Äôai fait pendant 12 ans du conventionnel et en 2010 je suis pass√© en bio. 
- Alors tu nous dis que tu es en bio depuis 11 ans qu‚Äôest-ce qui t‚Äôa fait te convertir au bio ?
Il y a plusieurs raisons. Une des raisons : je me suis rendu compte que je produisais essentiellement du bl√© dur et du tournesol. Le bl√© dur √©tait essentiellement commercialis√© via des coop√©ratives pour le Maghreb pour la semoule et en Italie pour les p√¢tes essentiellement et le tournesol lui, partait pour faire de l‚Äôhuile. Rien n‚Äô√©tait consomm√© localement et nous √©tions concurrenc√©s par d‚Äôautres pays, le Canda pour le bl√© dur notamment. D‚Äôun autre c√¥t√©, on avait d√©j√† en 2010 des consommateurs qui √©taient pr√™ts √† consommer local √† payer un juste prix pour une production de qualit√©. Il y a eu ces deux param√®tres, en plus de l‚Äôenvironnement social et naturel, car on est entour√© de maisons. Et c‚Äô√©tait de plus en plus compliqu√©, de pouvoir travailler en conventionnel, de pouvoir traiter, de pouvoir d√©sherber‚Ä¶ √ßa reste compliqu√©. 
- Est-ce que ce c√¥t√© local et terroir, √ßa a du sens ?
- C‚Äôest tout le sens du paysan. Il ne faut pas oublier que dans le mot paysan, il y a le mot pays, il y a le mot ¬´ territoire ¬ª et chaque paysan a son territoire. C‚Äôest ce qui nous reconna√Æt, c‚Äôest notre identit√©. 
- √áa fait donc dix ans que tu fais des l√©gumineuses, que tu es en bio, que tu transformes une partie de tes graines et que tu fais de la vente directe, est-ce que tu n‚Äôas pas √©t√© un peu pr√©curseur ? 
- On peut dire √ßa. Quand j‚Äôai commenc√© √† passer en bio, mon syst√®me d‚Äôexploitation a √©t√© con√ßu autour des l√©gumineuses, pour √™tre le plus autonome possible sur la production. A c√¥t√© de √ßa, toute la vente qu‚Äôon a pu mettre en place, on a vu au fil du temps la client√®le changer. Au d√©part, on travaillait avec des magasins fermiers, apr√®s √ßa √©t√© plus des magasins bio, et de plus en plus des magasins en vrac, bio, sans aucun d√©chet, √ßa explose sur le territoire. Tous les politiques d√©veloppent ce qui est local sur le territoire pour l‚Äôalimentation, restauration collective et autre. 
- Alors puisque tu as √©t√© pr√©curseur‚Ä¶ dans 10 ans o√π en serons-nous c√¥t√© agricole ?
- Je pense que le foss√© va se creuser entre une alimentation de qualit√© comme on essaie de faire sous labels et une agriculture de masse, mondialis√©e comme on a d√©j√†, et qui le sera encore plus. Ce qui nous pose le plus de questionnements, c‚Äôest plut√¥t le changement climatique. C‚Äôest de plus en plus compliqu√© de produire et d‚Äôavoir une r√©gularit√© dans la production. √áa, c‚Äôest compliqu√©, surtout avec des l√©gumineuses qui ont des rendements assez al√©atoires. 
- Laurent, as-tu un dernier message pour changer le monde ?
- Pour changer le monde, il faudrait que les consommateurs aient conscience que dans leur fa√ßon de consommer, ils peuvent g√©n√©rer dans l‚Äôavenir des changements positifs. Si on consomme une alimentation saine, locale qui a n√©cessit√© peu d‚Äô√©nergie pour la produire on va favoriser l‚Äôenvironnement et la sant√© de l‚Äôhumain. 
- Donc il faut manger fran√ßais !
- Fran√ßais, local et sain. 
- Merci beaucoup Laurent
- Avec plaisir Agathe

titre_video: They don't want to be wrong.  #regenerativeagriculture #farmer #farmers
description:
Richard Teague, PhD, (retired) Professor of Grazing Ecosystems Ecology @tamu, works to understand grazing practices, and how pasture forage production and nutrient quality is affected by different grazing methods.

Teague: ‚ÄúIf you do a small plot experiment on a couple of meters by a couple of meters, that‚Äôll tell you something about that that‚Äôs going to be accurate. But what does that mean to the whole farming unit? That‚Äôs what‚Äôs missing in the world today. We‚Äôre producing papers and papers and papers about smaller and smaller things.‚Äù

Byck: ‚ÄúSo, the science isn‚Äôt replicating nature.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs the problem! Farmers spend thousands and thousands each year fighting with nature, because that‚Äôs what they‚Äôve been conditioned to think is necessary. We‚Äôre here to conduct rigorous, large scale science to prove that working WITH nature is the best way for farmers to save time and money. Soil health creates farmer wealth.

titre_video: Growing Edible Mushrooms on Used Coffee Grounds | Sustainable Urban Farming in Portugal
description:
Visit our website- https://northspore.com/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=nam-mushrooms-video&utm_content=homepage

Belgium native Natan Jauquemin created N√£m Mushrooms. Portugal's first environmentally conscious, circular economy mushroom farm that specializes in growing mushrooms on used coffee grounds from local cafes and restaurants. Today, N√£m is the primary mushroom producer for the bustling, and bright coastal city of Lisbon. 

N√£m is focused on reducing coffee waste by employing the use of rigorous, edible mushroom species. As mushroom mycelium decomposes its coffee substrate, it neutralizes the release of methane, a greenhouse gas more potent than carbon dioxide, while turning it into a valuable food source. Once the growing process is complete, spent mushroom ‚Äúblocks‚Äù are then donated to local farms as fertilizer for crops.

In this video, North Spore explores the symbiotic relationship between coffee culture and mushroom growing in 20th century Portugal; a country whose history with mushrooms was almost non-existent - until now. 

Follow N√£m Mushrooms by visiting their website or social media accounts!

https://nammushroom.com/ 

https://www.instagram.com/nam.mushroomfarm/

Mais c‚Äôest aussi une r√©flexion sur l‚Äôagriculture fran√ßaise : certains voudraient nous faire croire qu‚Äôelle est condamn√©e, d‚Äôautres nous disent qu‚Äôelle doit s‚Äôindustrialiser pour gagner la comp√©tition mondiale. Lauriane et Charles explorent d‚Äôautres pistes, tr√®s prometteuses. Plut√¥t que de travailler contre la nature, ils ont d√©cid√© de travailler avec elle, en suivant les principes de la permaculture. Leur terrain est humide ? Ils creuseront des √©tangs et planteront des arbres autour ! Ils √©l√®veront des √©crevisses dans l‚Äôeau, des abeilles et des porcs en dehors... Ainsi, petit √† petit, s‚Äôinvente une agriculture nouvelle, √©cologique, plus humaine, circulaire et tr√®s productive, qui tire le maximum d‚Äôun petit territoire sans jamais l‚Äô√©puiser.
Enfin, cet ouvrage est un guide d‚Äôinstallation. Les aspirants paysans, tout comme les simples curieux, trouveront dans l‚Äôexp√©rience de Lauriane et Charles une mine d‚Äôinformations utiles. D‚Äôautant qu‚Äôils n‚Äô√©ludent pas les questions fondamentales : combien √ßa co√ªte ? comment obtenir des aides ? o√π se former ? o√π vendre ? comment s‚Äôorganiser √† plusieurs ?

LES AUTEURS
Lauriane et Charles Durant : 2004 est la date de leur rencontre. Elle est de la ville, lui de la campagne. Elle r√™ve de changer le monde, lui de faire de l‚Äôagriculture biologique. √Ä eux deux, Lauriane et Charles vont r√©volutionner leur vie et celle des autres. Ils fondent une famille et ach√®tent leur microferme √† Schopperten, en Alsace. Persuad√©s que l‚Äôagriculture de demain est la solution, ils s‚Äôembarquent dans une aventure tout aussi passionnante que difficile. Bravant les instances administratives, surmontant les pannes et les difficult√©s, ils n‚Äôont de cesse de montrer qu‚Äôune microferme agro√©cologique s‚Äôinspirant de la permaculture ne peut que r√©ussir.

titre_video: Mauricio Bellon: Crop Evolution Under Domestication
description:
Crop evolution under domestication is a process that continues today in many parts of the Global South for numerous crops, driven by smallholder farmers growing native varieties of crops. They provide an "evolutionary" service to society by sustaining crop evolution that generates the broad and novel genetic variation necessary for crops to adapt to change, fundamental to achieve sustainable agricultural and food systems. 

Current agricultural development strategies and related policies sponsored by international and national development and research organizations, as well as private companies, are based on promoting higher crop productivity while discouraging crop evolution. In this talk, Gund MacMillan Scholar in Residence Mauricio Bellon discusses the need to rethink these strategies to find the right balance between high crop productivity and the delivery of evolutionary services to agriculture and food systems.

Mauricio R. Bellon is an independent scientist and Honorary Fellow at the National Commission for the Use and Knowledge of Biodiversity (CONABIO), Mexico. He received his MS and PhD in ecology from the University of California, Davis and his undergraduate degree in agronomy from the Universidad Aut√≥noma Metropolitana, Mexico. His research focuses on the reasons, incentives and dynamics of crop diversity in agricultural systems-both at the inter-specific and infra-specific levels-in the developing world. 

Previously, Mauricio was Coordinator of Studies on Agrobiodiversity at CONABIO. Before this he was Principal Scientist and Programme Director, Diversity for Livelihoods Programme, at Bioversity International (Italy). He also has worked for the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT, Mexico), the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI, The Philippines) and the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM). He is a member of the Mexican Academy of Science. 

Explore Gund events: https://www.uvm.edu/gund/events
Learn more about MacMillan Scholars in Residence: https://www.uvm.edu/gund/visiting-scholars

titre_video: Retour sur le cycle de visites Bois et r√©emploi en IDF : Projet 3 - Envie le Labo (93)
ANIMAL HABITATS | Learn about Grasslands, Forests, Tundra, Desert, Rainforest, Mountains, Oceans
description:
Animal Habitats. This is a short documentary to get to know animal habitats. Subscribe to the Kiddopedia channel for more animal videos ‚Üí https://kiddopedia.page.link/sub

What is a habitat? Habitat is where an organism lives. All organisms that survive on earth continue to exist in an area called habitat. Habitat is the unique habitat of a species, animal, or plant. The survival time of species depends on their adaptation to the area in which they live. Because of this, the habitat of each species is different. Creatures belonging to the same species can live in different habitats. Different species can live in the same habitat.

The word habitat comes from Latin in origin and the meaning of the word in this language is 'the natural space of living things'. Habitats may differ according to the species, structures, and living conditions of living things. At this point, mostly air, water, and soil become habitats for organisms.

In this Kiddopedia documentary video, you will see the 8 main habitats of the world and the animals living in these habitats.

You will see the animals habitat in this video prepared by the Kiddopedia team in 4k documentary format.

SUBSCRIBE ‚Üí https://kiddopedia.page.link/sub
Check out our website ‚Üí http://kiddopedia.net

titre_video: Le Marc de Caf√© au Potager Bonne ou Mauvaise Id√©e
description:
Bonjour les Amis,

Je vous invite aujourd‚Äôhui √† partager avec moi une tasse de caf√© et √† explorer les bienfaits du marc de caf√© au potager. C‚Äôest une vid√©o importante sur un sujet qui fait pol√©mique et qui √©clairci ce sujet sur nourrir le sol de son potager.

Bon visionnage¬†!

Je vois sur les r√©seaux pas mal de non compr√©hension de mon discours suite aux √©tudes japonaise sur les effets inhibiteurs du marc de caf√© (d√ª sans doute au non visionnage jusqu'au bout de la vid√©o).

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1626/pps.17.93

L'√©tude japonaise dit que l'√©tude a √©t√© men√© sur des parcelles ou l'on semer de l'engrais vert et ils ont √©pandu 10 kgs de marc de caf√© par m¬≤... Je vous mets au d√©fi d'en avoir autant. Alors oui, les inhibiteurs ont emp√™ch√© la pousse des engrais vert.

Cependant, les effets inhibiteurs ont spontan√©ment diminu√© apr√®s la deuxi√®me saison de culture (environ 12 mois plus tard), et la croissance de l'herbe de Guin√©e, du sorgho et du tournesol √©tait environ 2 fois plus √©lev√©e que celle du t√©moin. L'√©pandage de fumier de cheval √† 10 kg/m¬≤ efficacement att√©nu√© les effets inhibiteurs, m√™me si la forte concentration de marc de caf√© √©tait incluse.

Dans cette m√™me ann√©e ils ont ensuite √©pandu 10 kg/m¬≤ de fumier et malgr√© l'ajout de 16 kg/m¬≤ de marc de caf√©, les effets n'ont √©t√© maintenu que durant 6 mois.

L'application de marc de caf√© a effectivement augment√© les teneurs en carbone et en azote du sol et a r√©duit le rapport C/N. Les effets de l'amendement du sol √©taient significativement plus √©lev√©s en termes d'enrichissement en azote et d'am√©lioration du ratio C/N par rapport √† l'application de fumier de cheval. Ces r√©sultats indiquent que le marc de caf√© est utile pour am√©liorer la croissance des cultures √† long terme, le contr√¥le des mauvaises herbes √† court terme et l'am√©lioration des sols dans les champs agricoles en tenant compte des effets inhibiteurs sur la croissance des plantes pendant six mois apr√®s l'application. L'utilisation agricole du marc de caf√© a √©galement √©t√© discut√©e en termes de p√©riodes de jach√®re dans la rotation des cultures.

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1626/pps.17.93

titre_video: Multi-function smoker built from scraps for nearly free - Homestead Hardware
description:
How we built and how we use our smoker - cold smoke, hot smoke, coffee drier, jerky dehydrator and more. 

We are a family transforming a mostly-untouched 30 acre jungle mountain into a working, self-sustainable, off-grid farm. There are a lot of trials, errors, successes, and lessons to be learned along the way. We hope to share it all with you, to tell our story, to inspire, and to hopefully help answer the questions you didn‚Äôt know to ask.

titre_video: Man Creates INCREDIBLE Small-scale Sustainable NATURAL FARM
description:
Thomas has created an incredible small-scale sustainable natural farm in Japan. The small-scale sustainable natural farm that Thomas Kloepfer started after the Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011, and which he runs together with his wife Kaori in Hiroshima, Japan, is proof that growing food using natural farming principles can be hugely productive AND environmentally sound. 

In this video, Thomas shares the story of his small-scale organic farm, describes his experience with natural farming, and shows how growing food naturally is working on his farm. This video is for anyone interested in how a homestead and abundance can be created through lots of intelligent design, hard work, goodwill, and careful observation of the natural environment. There's a bunch of valuable insights into how food systems can truly be made sustainable in this video! There's valuable info also related to permaculture techniques, organic gardening more generally, ecological orchards, Masanobu Fukuoka, the state of organic food in Japan, abandoned farmland in Japan, seed saving, using sheep and goats as helpers on the farm, polyculture, interplanting, intensive organic market garden, etc. 

Help me make more videos like this one by joining my Patreon site! My videos are entirely self-funded at this point!

titre_video: 7 Reasons Why You Should Grow Vegetables In Containers
description:
7 Reasons You NEED to Grow Vegetables In Containers | Self-Sufficiency | Guten Yardening

We think that container gardening is one of the most effective ways of utilizing all available space for gardening.  One of the things we know is that not everyone has the best soil, or the largest garden plot, and so this is one option to make sure you don‚Äôt waste any space.

In this video we focus on why we believe container gardening to be such an important addition to any garden.  We talk about the size, flexibility, and so much more.

We have been gardening in a wide variety of containers for several years, and we have found that there are few limits to what can be grown.  When you grow vegetables in containers, you will see that this is a great intro into gardening as well.

If you have been gardening for a long time, but have never tried growing vegetables in containers, we think the reasons we list will be a good motivator for you as well.

At a time of food shortages and soaring prices, and when self sufficiency is more important than ever, whether you are a prepper or a new gardener, container gardening will be a difference maker for you.

titre_video: Installer un puits canadien
description:
Vous souhaitez installer un puits canadien ? üëâ https://puits-canadien.ooreka.fr/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=ZA_1&utm_campaign=P159


========================================

Le puits canadien est un proc√©d√© g√©othermique qui utilise la capacit√© du sol √† garder la m√™me temp√©rature, pour r√©chauffer ou refroidir l‚Äôair ambiant d‚Äôune habitation. 
L‚Äôair ext√©rieur aspir√© passe dans un conduit souterrain et est ensuite ventil√© dans la maison.
Le proc√©d√© est √©cologique, durable et permet de r√©aliser jusqu‚Äô√† 20 % d'√©conomies d‚Äô√©nergie.

Avant tout, r√©alisez une √©tude thermique de votre habitation par un professionnel pour conna√Ætre :
- Les besoins √©nerg√©tiques et de renouvellement d‚Äôair.
- La nature du sol, notamment son potentiel et sa conductivit√© thermique.
- Les dimensions des conduits n√©cessaires et l‚Äôenvironnement souterrain.

√Ä quoi penser d‚Äôautre ?
- A la profondeur : pour un rendement optimal les conduits doivent √™tre enterr√©s √† une profondeur minimum de 1 m√®tre 10. Plus la profondeur est grande plus la temp√©rature du sol est constante.
- A une VMC double flux coupl√©e √† votre installation pour une meilleure ventilation.
- A la borne de prise d‚Äôair √† minimum 1 m√®tre 20  du sol pour √©viter l‚Äôaspiration de poussi√®res ou de polluants.

Maintenant, combien √ßa co√ªte ? Comptez 2000 euros minimum selon la qualit√© du mat√©riel et les dimensions de l‚Äôinstallation. Ajoutez :
- Les frais de l‚Äô√©tude thermique d‚Äôenviron 2500 euros.
- L‚Äôinstallation d‚Äôune VMC, 2 000 euros, et un √©ventuel terrassement.

Pour votre installation, il est recommand√© de passer par un professionnel. Cela offre plusieurs avantages :
-    Un travail de qualit√©.
-    Une TVA r√©duite.
-    Une garantie sur l‚Äôinstallation.
Comptez au minimum 1000 euros l‚Äôinstallation. 

Le puits canadien est une infrastructure √©nerg√©tique tr√®s rentable √† long-terme. Avant de faire votre choix, √©tudiez la rentabilit√© du projet.

Une fois extrait, le fumier est transport√© dans le haut du Seconov, o√π un r√¢teau m√©canique l‚Äô√©tend en une fine couche. Par un tunnel en communication avec la grange et √† l‚Äôaide de puissants ventilateurs, le syst√®me utilise la chaleur d√©gag√©e par les propres volailles pour s√©cher la couche de fumier. Une fois s√®che, elle chute dans le fond du tunnel d‚Äôo√π, apr√®s une autre op√©ration de s√©chage, elle est transf√©r√©e √† l‚Äôentrep√¥t. titre_video: Conserving the Nature of America in a Changing Climate
description: Worldwide scientific consensus tells us that climate change is real and even now is impacting our nation's ecosystems--the forests, grasslands, wetlands, and oceans that provide our air and water, and also provide food and shelter for self-sustaining fish and wildlife populations. These natural systems and wildlife resources also sustain people by providing food, jobs, and recreation. As climate changes, the abundance and distribution of fish and wildlife will also change. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and other resource agencies will need an engaged and informed public to help make decisions how best to respond to climate change impacts, and to help find solutions to eventually halt and reverse accelerating climate change.

titre_video: Harvest scallions
description:
The automatic scallion harvester has the following benefits and advantages:
 
- Improve harvesting efficiency: Compared with manual harvesting, the automatic scallion harvester can quickly complete a series of processes such as digging, conveying, and cleaning. It can harvest a large quantity of scallions in a short period of time, greatly shortening the harvesting cycle, and is especially suitable for farmers and farms with large-scale scallion plantations.
 
- Reduce labor intensity: Manual harvesting of scallions requires long hours of bending over, digging, and carrying, which is extremely labor-intensive. However, the automatic scallion harvester can achieve mechanized operation, and the operator only needs to control the equipment in the cab, greatly reducing physical labor.
 
- Reduce damage to scallions: Professional automatic scallion harvesters are equipped with reasonable digging and conveying devices. They can operate according to the growth characteristics of scallions and soil conditions, effectively avoiding damage to scallions caused by improper force or unreasonable use of tools during manual harvesting, and improving the commercial rate of scallions.
 
- Stable harvesting quality: The operating parameters of the automatic scallion harvester can be precisely adjusted, such as digging depth and conveying speed. It can ensure relatively consistent harvesting quality under different field and soil conditions, so that the soil at the roots of the harvested scallions is cleaned thoroughly and the scallions are neatly arranged, facilitating subsequent sorting and transportation.
 
- Save costs: In the long run, although there is a certain initial investment required to purchase an automatic scallion harvester, it can reduce the dependence on labor and lower labor costs. Moreover, the high efficiency of mechanized operation allows scallions to be harvested and put on the market in a timely manner, avoiding losses caused by untimely harvesting, thus improving the planting efficiency.

titre_video: √âCO-VILLAGES : UN AUTRE MOD√àLE DE SOCI√âT√â
description:
Depuis le confinement, on parle beaucoup d‚Äô√©co-village, tout quitter pour aller vivre plus proche de la nature, consommer local, lutter contre la pr√©carit√©. Mais que repr√©sentent r√©ellement ces alternatives ? Est-ce compl√®tement utopique ?

Il y a plus de 2000 √©co-lieux en France, tous tr√®s diff√©rents les uns des autres. Tera a √©t√© cr√©√© en 2015, initialement sous forme d‚Äô√©co-hameau √† la ferme de Lartel, dans le Lot et Garonne, √† une heure de Toulouse. Ne pouvant pas construire sur ce terrain pour des questions de normes et de relations avec la commune de Masqui√®res, peu √† peu chacun a pris des logements aux alentours dans les communes voisines. Aujourd'hui l'association rassemble une cinquantaine de personnes venues s'installer sur la commune de Tournon d‚ÄôAgenais principalement, et bient√¥t sur la commune de Trentels.

Tera ce n'est plus simplement un √©co-lieu, c'est tout un √©co-syst√®me sur un rayon de 30km bas√© sur un mod√®le √©conomique alternatif exp√©rimentant une monnaie citoyenne locale et un revenu d'autonomie.

Le but ? Revitaliser les communes en favorisant les √©changes de produits locaux et respectueux de l'environnement, mais aussi ne pas d√©pendre de march√©s financiers en se r√©appropriant le pouvoir mon√©taire. La richesse produite sur le territoire sera alors redistribu√©e √† terme sous forme d'un revenu de base vers√© de mani√®re inconditionnelle √† chacun d√®s la naissance, sous forme de monnaie locale √† 85%.

Un projet encore en exp√©rimentation √† Tera qui a vers√© ses 5 premiers revenus d‚Äôautonomie en 2018, notamment pour le mara√Æchage, la gestion, et la construction de toilettes s√®ches. Un revenu index√© sur la production locale, qui mise sur la responsabilisation de chacun dans la gestion de son temps de travail et de ses activit√©s.

A terme, c‚Äôest aussi tout un √©co-quartier qui sera construit sur la commune voisine, √† Trentels, pour mettre en application ce revenu d'autonomie pour les 30 futurs habitant. Un projet qui n√©cessite une dizaine de structures juridiques, dont la scic (une soci√©t√© coop√©rative d‚Äôint√©r√™t collectif).

Aujourd'hui, Tera exp√©rimente encore les bases de ce syst√®me, notamment sur le versement du revenu d'autonomie et l'utilisation de la monnaie locale (l'enjeu est de convaincre de plus en plus de producteurs locaux de l'utiliser). Un projet en perp√©tuelle r√©flexion via le suivi par un conseil scientifique rassemblant des chercheurs en √©conomie, en organisation du travail, en philosophie et en gestion des conflits.

Une exp√©rience locale qui, en ces temps de remise en cause du syst√®me et de crise √©conomique, pourrait inspirer des solutions pour r√©pondre aux in√©galit√©s, aux probl√®mes environnementaux, au ch√¥mage, mais aussi donner une nouvelle conception du travail.

QUEL EST L'AVENIR DU MOUVEMENT DES COOP√âRATIVES D'HABITATION ?

Quels liens existent parmi les coop√©ratives d‚Äôhabitations et lesquels pouvent √™tre d√©velopp√©s ? Quelles perspetives collectives adopter localement ? Quel r√¥le joue l‚Äô√©chelle municipale ?  O√π en sommes-nous apr√®s pr√®s de 50 ans de d√©veloppement de coop√©ratives ?  

Ce panel discute des d√©fis qui portent autant sur la pr√©servation du patrimoine b√¢ti que sur les enjeux sociaux li√©s au vivre-ensemble et des perspectives pour le d√©veloppement futur du mouvement.

CHAIR: Norma Rantisi (Concordia)
-- Louise Constantin (F√©d√©ration des coop√©ratives d‚Äôhabitation intermunicipale du Montr√©al m√©tropolitain (FECHIMM))
-- Fran√ßois Dansereau-Laberge (Intercoop Verdun, Pr√©sident de la coop√©rative d‚Äôhabitation Parc Therrien)
-- Josh Hawley (co-auteur de ¬´ Villages in Cities ¬ª, chercheur √† l‚ÄôUniversit√© Queens).

Film√© dans le cadre du colloque √Ä nous les quartiers // From the Ground Up, au Centre Canadien d'Architecture √† Montr√©al, les 12, 13 et 14 avril 2019, avec la participation de plus que 400 participants et 30 ateliers et activit√©s.

WHAT IS THE FUTURE OF THE COOPERATIVE HOUSING MOVEMENT?

How can housing cooperatives develop links with each other and build a collaboration with the broader cooperative movement and socio-political struggles to transform society?

The cooperative movement in housing is organized to be locally dynamic and a social movement of importance. Where do we stand after nearly 50 years of cooperative development? This panel explores as much on the preservation of built heritage as on social issues related to living together and perspectives for the future.

-- Louise Constantin, (Advisor on associative and political affairs, Federation of housing cooperatives in metropolitan Montreal -- FECHIMM)

titre_video: Desert Homestead Vegetable Varieties (2022 Spring Garden) | Seed Haul
description:
This is a complete list of seeds I have started this year to grow in my garden for the spring/summer garden season. Both ornamental flowers and edible vegetables are included. Some of these varieties I have grown before, but some are new to me this year and I am very excited to get to try them with you all!

Finding good varieties to grow in the arid climate of the desert southwest can be difficult. I am always experimenting year after year to see what works, and what doesn't, and which varieties will increase my self-sufficiency in the years to come. 

All of the seeds companies mentioned here I have purchase from before, and they are good companies with good products and values. (in my opinion). I am not affiliated with any of these seed companies, but I think they deserve a shout-out because they are awesome!

Splitting Firewood by Hand with an Axe | Traditional Wood Cutting Technique
description:
In this satisfying, silent video, you'll watch the traditional method of splitting firewood by hand using nothing more than an axe and muscle. Even though the video has no narration, this description explains the full process and purpose of manual wood cutting ‚Äî a time-honored skill for anyone living off the land, homesteading, or preparing for winter.

Splitting wood is more than just brute force ‚Äî it requires technique, timing, and understanding the grain of the log. It‚Äôs an essential part of rural living and survival, especially in areas where wood is used for heating, cooking, or building.

üìå What You‚Äôll See in This Video:

Positioning logs upright on a sturdy chopping block
Using a full-sized axe to split firewood cleanly
Striking at the natural cracks or center of the wood grain
Watching logs split apart with precision and efficiency
Repeating the process with both small and large pieces
üìå Why Manual Wood Splitting Still Matters:

A key survival and homestead skill
Helps reduce dependency on power tools or fuel-based machines
Builds strength, coordination, and respect for traditional labor
Offers a sustainable, eco-friendly method of preparing firewood
This video is perfect for those interested in bushcraft, off-grid living, rural life, or traditional skills. It‚Äôs also surprisingly therapeutic and satisfying to watch ‚Äî seeing each log crack open with a well-placed swing never gets old.
